1085    /**
1086     * A variation on {@link Math#cos(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians (it
1087     * also takes and returns a float); one turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a
1088     * building block for other measurements; to make a cosine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal
1089     * to 360 degrees), you would just divide the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this
1090     * method. Similarly for binary degrees, also called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by
1091     * 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you
1092     * can use a byte for any brad values, and adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0)
1093     * while keeping perfect precision for the results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this
1094     * method).
1095     * <br>
1096     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #cos_(double)}, so you should
1097     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
1098     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
1099     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
1100     * and likewise for doubles.
1101     * <br>
1102     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
1103     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
1104     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
1105     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a float, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
1106     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a float between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
1107     */
1108    public static float cos_(float turns)
1109    {
1110        turns = turns * 4f + 1f;
1111        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
1112        turns -= floor;
1113        turns *= 2f - turns;
1114        return turns * (-0.775f - 0.225f * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
1115    }
1116
1117    /**
1118     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
1119     * approximation. Maximum error is below 0.001 radians.
1120     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in radians.
1121     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
1122     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
1123     * MathUtils approximation of the same method; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
1124     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
1125     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
1126     * handy information that makes this approach usable. This method changed from an earlier
1127     * technique that was twice as fast but had very poor quality, enough to be visually noticeable. See also
1128     * {@link #atan2_(double, double)} if you don't want a mess converting to degrees or some other measurement, since
1129     * that method returns an angle from 0.0 (equal to 0 degrees) to 1.0 (equal to 360 degrees).
1130     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1131     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1132     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a double; ranges from -PI to PI
1133     */
1134    public static double atan2(double y, double x)
1135    {
1136        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0.0;
1137        double ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
1138        boolean invert = ay > ax;
1139        double z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
1140        z = ((((0.141499  * z) - 0.343315 ) * z - 0.016224 ) * z + 1.003839 ) * z - 0.000158 ;
1141        if (invert) z = 1.5707963267948966 - z;
1142        if (x < 0) z = 3.141592653589793 - z;
1143        return Math.copySign(z, y);
1144    }
1145
1146    /**
1147     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
1148     * approximation. Maximum error is below 0.001 radians.
1149     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in radians.
1150     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
1151     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
1152     * MathUtils approximation of the same method; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
1153     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
1154     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
1155     * handy information that makes this approach usable. This method changed from an earlier
1156     * technique that was twice as fast but had very poor quality, enough to be visually noticeable. See also
1157     * {@link #atan2_(float, float)} if you don't want a mess converting to degrees or some other measurement, since
1158     * that method returns an angle from 0f (equal to 0 degrees) to 1f (equal to 360 degrees).
1159     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1160     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1161     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a float; ranges from -PI to PI
1162     */
1163    public static float atan2(float y, float x) {
1164        if (y == 0f && x >= 0f) return 0f;
1165        float ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
1166        boolean invert = ay > ax;
1167        float z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
1168        z = ((((0.141499f * z) - 0.343315f) * z - 0.016224f) * z + 1.003839f) * z - 0.000158f;
1169        if (invert) z = 1.5707963267948966f - z;
1170        if (x < 0) z = 3.141592653589793f - z;
1171        return Math.copySign(z, y);
1172    }
1173
1174    /**
1175     * Altered-range approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, taking y and x positions as 
1176     * doubles and returning an angle measured in turns from 0.0 to 1.0 (inclusive), with one cycle over the range
1177     * equivalent to 360 degrees or 2PI radians. You can multiply the angle by {@code 6.2831855f} to change to radians,
1178     * or by {@code 360f} to change to degrees. Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles. Will never return a
1179     * negative number, which may help avoid costly floating-point modulus when you actually want a positive number.
1180     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
1181     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
1182     * handy information that makes this approach usable. Note that
1183     * {@link #atan2(double, double)} returns an angle in radians and can return negative results, which may be fine for
1184     * many tasks; these two methods are extremely close in implementation and speed.
1185     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1186     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1187     * @return the angle to the given point, as a double from 0.0 to 1.0, inclusive
1188     */
1189    public static double atan2_(double y, double x)
1190    {
1191        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0.0;
1192        double ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
1193        boolean invert = ay > ax;
1194        double z = invert ? ax/ay : ay/ax;
1195        z = (((((0.022520265292560102) * z) - (0.054640279287594046)) * z - (0.0025821297967229097)) * z + (0.1597659389184251)) * z - (0.000025146481008519463);
1196        if(invert) z = 0.25 - z;
1197        if(x < 0) z = 0.5 - z;
1198        return y < 0 ? (int)(1+z) - z : z;
1199
1200    }
1201    /**
1202     * Altered-range approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, taking y and x positions as floats
1203     * and returning an angle measured in turns from 0.0f to 1.0f, with one cycle over the range equivalent to 360
1204     * degrees or 2PI radians. You can multiply the angle by {@code 6.2831855f} to change to radians, or by {@code 360f}
1205     * to change to degrees. Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats. Will never return a negative number, which
1206     * may help avoid costly floating-point modulus when you actually want a positive number.
1207     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
1208     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
1209     * handy information that makes this approach usable. Note that
1210     * {@link #atan2(float, float)} returns an angle in radians and can return negative results, which may be fine for
1211     * many tasks; these two methods are extremely close in implementation and speed.
1212     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1213     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1214     * @return the angle to the given point, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive
1215     */
1216    public static float atan2_(float y, float x)
1217    {
1218        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0f;
1219        float ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
1220        boolean invert = ay > ax;
1221        float z = invert ? ax/ay : ay/ax;
1222        z = (((((0.022520265292560102f) * z) - (0.054640279287594046f)) * z - (0.0025821297967229097f)) * z + (0.1597659389184251f)) * z - (0.000025146481008519463f);
1223        if(invert) z = 0.25f - z;
1224        if(x < 0) z = 0.5f - z;
1225        return y < 0 ? (int)(1+z) - z : z;
1226    }
1227
1228    /**
1229     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
1230     * approximation, and giving a result in degrees from -180 to 180. Maximum error is below 0.1 degrees.
1231     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
1232     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
1233     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
1234     * MathUtils approximation after converting to degrees; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
1235     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
1236     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
1237     * handy information that makes this approach usable.
1238     * <br>
1239     * See also {@link #atan2Degrees360(double, double)}, which is just like this but returns an angle from 0 to 360,
1240     * instead of -180 to 180, in case negative angles are undesirable.
1241     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1242     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1243     * @return the angle to the given point, in degrees as a double
1244     */
1245    public static double atan2Degrees(double y, double x)
1246    {
1247        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0.0;
1248        double ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
1249        boolean invert = ay > ax;
1250        double z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
1251        z = (((((8.107295505321636)  * z) - (19.670500543533855) ) * z - (0.9295667268202475) ) * z + (57.51573801063304) ) * z - (0.009052733163067006) ;
1252        if (invert) z = 90 - z;
1253        if (x < 0) z = 180 - z;
1254        return Math.copySign(z, y);
1255    }
1256
1257    /**
1258     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
1259     * approximation, and giving a result in degrees from -180 to 180. Maximum error is below 0.1 degrees.
1260     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
1261     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
1262     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
1263     * MathUtils approximation after converting to degrees; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
1264     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
1265     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
1266     * handy information that makes this approach usable.
1267     * <br>
1268     * See also {@link #atan2Degrees360(float, float)}, which is just like this but returns an angle from 0 to 360,
1269     * instead of -180 to 180, in case negative angles are undesirable.
1270     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1271     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1272     * @return the angle to the given point, in degrees as a float
1273     */
1274    public static float atan2Degrees(float y, float x)
1275    {
1276        if(y == 0f && x >= 0f) return 0f;
1277        float ax = Math.abs(x), ay = Math.abs(y);
1278        boolean invert = ay > ax;
1279        float z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
1280        z = (((((8.107295505321636f)  * z) - (19.670500543533855f) ) * z - (0.9295667268202475f) ) * z + (57.51573801063304f) ) * z - (0.009052733163067006f) ;
1281        if (invert) z = 90 - z;
1282        if (x < 0) z = 180 - z;
1283        return Math.copySign(z, y);
1284    }
1285
1286    /**
1287     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
1288     * approximation, and giving a result in degrees from 0 to 360 (both inclusive). Maximum error is below 0.1 degrees.
1289     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
1290     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
1291     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
1292     * MathUtils approximation after converting to degrees; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
1293     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
1294     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
1295     * handy information that makes this approach usable.
1296     * <br>
1297     * See also {@link #atan2Degrees(double, double)}, which is just like this but returns an angle from -180 to 180,
1298     * matching {@link Math#atan2(double, double)}'s convention.
1299     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1300     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1301     * @return the angle to the given point, in degrees as a double
1302     */
1303    public static double atan2Degrees360(double y, double x)
1304    {
1305        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0.0;
1306        double ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
1307        boolean invert = ay > ax;
1308        double z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
1309        z = (((((8.107295505321636)  * z) - (19.670500543533855) ) * z - (0.9295667268202475) ) * z + (57.51573801063304) ) * z - (0.009052733163067006) ;
1310        if (invert) z = 90 - z;
1311        if (x < 0) z = 180 - z;
1312        return y < 0 ? 360 - z : z;
1313    }
1314    /**
1315     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
1316     * approximation, and giving a result in degrees from 0 to 360 (both inclusive). Maximum error is below 0.1 degrees.
1317     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
1318     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
1319     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
1320     * MathUtils approximation after converting to degrees; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
1321     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
1322     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
1323     * handy information that makes this approach usable.
1324     * <br>
1325     * See also {@link #atan2Degrees(float, float)}, which is just like this but returns an angle from -180 to 180,
1326     * matching {@link Math#atan2(double, double)}'s convention.
1327     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1328     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
1329     * @return the angle to the given point, in degrees as a float
1330     */
1331    public static float atan2Degrees360(float y, float x)
1332    {
1333        if(y == 0f && x >= 0f) return 0f;
1334        float ax = Math.abs(x), ay = Math.abs(y);
1335        boolean invert = ay > ax;
1336        float z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
1337        z = (((((8.107295505321636f)  * z) - (19.670500543533855f) ) * z - (0.9295667268202475f) ) * z + (57.51573801063304f) ) * z - (0.009052733163067006f) ;
1338        if (invert) z = 90 - z;
1339        if (x < 0) z = 180 - z;
1340        return y < 0 ? 360 - z : z;
1341    }
1342
1343    /**
1344     * Arc sine approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study
1345     * "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 35's algorithm, which is the fastest
1346     * and least precise). This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#asin(double)}, but is somewhat less
1347     * precise than Math's implementation. It is currently the same as libGDX's approximation in their MathUtils.
1348     * @param x an input to the inverse sine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
1349     * @return an output from the inverse sine function, from PI/-2.0 to PI/2.0 inclusive.
1350     */
1351    public static float asin(final float x) {
1352        final float x2 = x * x;
1353        final float x3 = x * x2;
1354        if (x >= 0f) {
1355            return 1.5707963267948966f - (float) Math.sqrt(1f - x) *
1356                    (1.5707288f - 0.2121144f * x + 0.0742610f * x2 - 0.0187293f * x3);
1357        }
1358        else {
1359            return -1.5707964f + (float) Math.sqrt(1f + x) *
1360                    (1.5707288f + 0.2121144f * x + 0.0742610f * x2 + 0.0187293f * x3);
1361        }
1362    }
1363    /**
1364     * Arc cosine approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study
1365     * "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 35's algorithm, which is the fastest
1366     * and least precise). This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#acos(double)}, but is somewhat less
1367     * precise than Math's implementation. It is currently the same as libGDX's approximation in their MathUtils.
1368     * <br>
1369     * Accuracy: absolute error 0.000028450, relative error -0.000000011, max error 0.000067548 .
1370     * @param x an input to the inverse cosine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
1371     * @return an output from the inverse cosine function, from 0 to PI inclusive.
1372     */
1373    public static float acos(final float x) {
1374        final float x2 = x * x;
1375        final float x3 = x * x2;
1376        if (x >= 0f) {
1377            return (float) Math.sqrt(1f - x) * (1.5707288f - 0.2121144f * x + 0.0742610f * x2 - 0.0187293f * x3);
1378        }
1379        else {
1380            return 3.14159265358979323846f - (float) Math.sqrt(1f + x) * (1.5707288f + 0.2121144f * x + 0.0742610f * x2 + 0.0187293f * x3);
1381        }
1382    }
1383
1384    /**
1385     * Arc sine approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study
1386     * "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 35's algorithm, which is the fastest
1387     * and least precise). This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#asin(double)}, but is somewhat less
1388     * precise than Math's implementation. It is currently the same as libGDX's approximation in their MathUtils, except
1389     * that this takes a double and returns a double.
1390     * <br>
1391     * Accuracy: absolute error 0.000028447, relative error -0.000000033, max error 0.000067592 .
1392     * @param x an input to the inverse sine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
1393     * @return an output from the inverse sine function, from PI/-2.0 to PI/2.0 inclusive.
1394     */
1395    public static double asin(final double x) {
1396        final double x2 = x * x;
1397        final double x3 = x * x2;
1398        if (x >= 0.0) {
1399            return 1.5707963267948966 - Math.sqrt(1.0 - x) *
1400                    (1.5707288 - 0.2121144 * x + 0.0742610 * x2 - 0.0187293 * x3);
1401        }
1402        else {
1403            return -1.5707963267948966 + Math.sqrt(1.0 + x) *
1404                    (1.5707288 + 0.2121144 * x + 0.0742610 * x2 + 0.0187293 * x3);
1405        }
1406    }
1407    /**
1408     * Arc cosine approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study
1409     * "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 35's algorithm, which is the fastest
1410     * and least precise). This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#acos(double)}, but is somewhat less
1411     * precise than Math's implementation. It is currently the same as libGDX's approximation in their MathUtils, except
1412     * that this takes a double and returns a double.
1413     * <br>
1414     * Accuracy: absolute error 0.000028450, relative error -0.000000011, max error 0.000067548 .
1415     * @param x an input to the inverse cosine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
1416     * @return an output from the inverse cosine function, from 0 to PI inclusive.
1417     */
1418    public static double acos(final double x) {
1419        final double x2 = x * x;
1420        final double x3 = x * x2;
1421        if (x >= 0.0) {
1422            return Math.sqrt(1.0 - x) * (1.5707288 - 0.2121144 * x + 0.0742610 * x2 - 0.0187293 * x3);
1423        }
1424        else {
1425            return 3.14159265358979323846 - Math.sqrt(1.0 + x) * (1.5707288 + 0.2121144 * x + 0.0742610 * x2 + 0.0187293 * x3);
1426        }
1427    }
1428    /**
1429     * Inverse sine function (arcsine) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
1430     * range from 0.75 (inclusive) to 1.0 (exclusive), and continuing past that to 0.0 (inclusive) to 0.25 (inclusive).
1431     * <br>
1432     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation, but it never returns a negative result.
1433     * @param x a double from -1.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
1434     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #sin_(double)}
1435     */
1436    public static double asin_(final double x)
1437    {
1438        final double x2 = x * x;
1439        final double x3 = x * x2;
1440        if (x >= 0.0) {
1441            return 0.25 - Math.sqrt(1.0 - x) *
1442                    (0.24998925277680106 - 0.033759055260971525 * x + 0.01181900522894724 * x2 - 0.0029808606756510357 * x3);
1443        }
1444        else {
1445            return 0.75 + Math.sqrt(1.0 + x) *
1446                    (0.24998925277680106 + 0.033759055260971525 * x + 0.01181900522894724 * x2 + 0.0029808606756510357 * x3);
1447        }
1448    }
1449    /**
1450     * Inverse cosine function (arccos) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
1451     * range from 0.0 (inclusive) to 0.5 (inclusive).
1452     * <br>
1453     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
1454     * @param x a double from -1.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
1455     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #cos_(double)}
1456     */
1457    public static double acos_(final double x)
1458    {
1459        final double x2 = x * x;
1460        final double x3 = x * x2;
1461        if (x >= 0.0) {
1462            return Math.sqrt(1.0 - x) * (0.24998925277680106 - 0.033759055260971525 * x + 0.01181900522894724 * x2 - 0.0029808606756510357 * x3);
1463        }
1464        else {
1465            return 0.5 - Math.sqrt(1.0 + x) * (0.24998925277680106 + 0.033759055260971525 * x + 0.01181900522894724 * x2 + 0.0029808606756510357 * x3);
1466        }
1467    }

1470    /**
1471     * Inverse sine function (arcsine) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
1472     * range from 0.75f (inclusive) to 1.0f (exclusive), and continuing past that to 0.0f (inclusive) to 0.25f
1473     * (inclusive).
1474     * <br>
1475     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation, but it never returns a negative result.
1476     * @param x a float from -1.0f to 1.0f (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
1477     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #sin_(float)}
1478     */
1479    public static float asin_(final float x)
1480    {
1481        final float x2 = x * x;
1482        final float x3 = x * x2;
1483        if (x >= 0f) {
1484            return 0.25f - (float) Math.sqrt(1f - x) *
1485                    (0.24998925277680106f - 0.033759055260971525f * x + 0.01181900522894724f * x2 - 0.0029808606756510357f * x3);
1486        }
1487        else {
1488            return 0.75f + (float) Math.sqrt(1f + x) *
1489                    (0.24998925277680106f + 0.033759055260971525f * x + 0.01181900522894724f * x2 + 0.0029808606756510357f * x3);
1490        }
1491    }
1492    /**
1493     * Inverse cosine function (arccos) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
1494     * range from 0.0f (inclusive) to 0.5f (inclusive).
1495     * <br>
1496     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
1497     * @param x a float from -1.0f to 1.0f (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
1498     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #cos_(float)}
1499     */
1500    public static float acos_(final float x)
1501    {
1502        final float x2 = x * x;
1503        final float x3 = x * x2;
1504        if (x >= 0f) {
1505            return (float) Math.sqrt(1f - x) * (0.24998925277680106f - 0.033759055260971525f * x + 0.01181900522894724f * x2 - 0.0029808606756510357f * x3);
1506        }
1507        else {
1508            return 0.5f - (float) Math.sqrt(1f + x) * (0.24998925277680106f + 0.033759055260971525f * x + 0.01181900522894724f * x2 + 0.0029808606756510357f * x3);
1509        }
1510    }

1551//    /**
1552//     * Arc cosine approximation with fairly low error while still being faster than {@link NumberTools#cos(float)}.
1553//     * This formula is number 201 in <a href=">http://www.fastcode.dk/fastcodeproject/articles/index.htm">Dennis
1554//     * Kjaer Christensen's unfinished math work on arc sine approximation</a>, with a basic change to go from arc sine
